Apostrophes

If the comma is the devil’s tadpole then the apostrophe is the flying tadpole.

Apostrophes have two main uses. One is to indicate a missing letter or letters in a word or phrase. A contraction such as wasn’t for was not, for example, or ‘neath, for underneath. Alternatively it is used to indicate possession. There are other uses but they are minor and unusual.

The apostrophe stands in contrast the comma. As we saw, the comma can be quite a tricky little blighter to sprinkle correctly in sentences but it doesn’t really have the reputation of being difficult that, perhaps, it should.

The apostrophe is the other way round. It tends to be thought as more difficult but is, in fact, relatively straightforward. Why is this?

In part, I suspect, it is the work of that feared division of the grammar Nazis, the punctuation police. Nothing, not a split infinitive (which, as we will see, is perfectly permissible in English) nor turning a noun into a verb enrages the pedantic soul more than a misplaced apostrophe. This is so much so that there is now a term, ‘the grocer’s apostrophe’ for the most popular apostrophic error.

The grocer’s apostrophe (sometimes ‘the greengrocer’s apostrophe’) is when a possessive apostrophe is put where it is not required, usually in a plural. A greengrocer might write Apple’s for example, unaware that the apples in question don’t possess anything and that the s simply informs the reader that a plurality of apples are for sale.

The grocer’s apostrophe sends grammar Nazis into paroxysms of mouth frothing rage. But while this is always amusing it is unnecessary. After all, if you see a market stall with ‘apple’s for sale,’ sign, you are unlikely to be confused about what it is these apples could possibly posses (a healthy sheen? a delicious taste? The texture of cardboard?) You will simply assume that there is more than one of them. As the function of English is communication and no miscommunication has occurred it hardly seems worth jumping up and down with steam coming out of your ears. If, however, you are writing for publication or marking it important to avoid it.

The possessive apostrophe is used to indicate possession but that might be broader than is at first obvious. For example, inanimate objects can posses things, as we saw with the apple’s delicious taste. October’s gales, fear’s deadly embrace, time’s arrow… even abstract nouns can possess, and require an apostrophe.

Still, possessive apostrophes are pretty straightforward except… It does get a bit more complex when the noun already ends with an s and with plurals.

Singular nouns with s endings move the apostrophe beyond the last letter, or we add an extra s:

‘Dicken’s book, Hard Times’ is wrong, his name is Dickens not Dicken. So it becomes Dickens’ book or Dickens’s.

Which is correct? It’s a style question. If writing for publication check the style guide.

This freedom only applies to singular words that end in s.

Many plurals are formed by adding an s and if that needs a possessive apostrophe you just add it to the end: the starlings’ murmuration.

There is one big exception to the usual rule about possessive apostrophes and that is with possessive pronouns: its, our, their etc. In the case of its it might seem odd that it doesn’t take an apostrophe in the case of: The river meandered its way.’ But bear in mind the other main use of apostrophes. It’s is a contraction. It’s short for it is.

To quote Grammarly: “Most writers don’t have trouble with the possessive pronouns my, mine, his, her, and our. It’s your, yours, hers, its, ours, their, and theirs that tend to cause the confusion. The relative possessive pronoun whose is also frequently the victim of apostrophe abuse. Note that none of these forms use an apostrophe.”

The second main use of the apostrophe is to signify missing letters. We have seen the contraction it’s for it is. Wasn’t for was not, can’t for cannot are other common examples. Sometimes it is just a part of a word that is missing, ‘cause for because, for example. You will no doubt have noticed that this tends very much to be informal language and when letters are missing from the front of a word, often slang, dialect or archaic. The main exception is o’clock, which stands for of the clock which sounds odd and outdated.

We are talking about English so, of course, there are obscure exceptions. If you want to check them out Grammarly is as thorough as usual: https://www.grammarly.com/blog/apostrophe/#:~:text=Using%20an%20unnecessary%20apostrophe%20to,do%20not%20make%20nouns%20plural.

Otherwise, here are the main things to remember:

Apostrophes are used to indicate possession or missing letters. They are not normally used to make a plural (even of bananas).

Possessive apostrophes go before a possessive s which is added to the word, except when the word ends in s already.

Singular words that end in s can move the apostrophe beyond the last letter: Dickens’ fame or can add a second s: Dickens’s parrot. This is a style choice which means it might be a rule for some publishers. Otherwise just decide and stick to whichever you choose, at least in the same document.

Plural words, just move the apostrophe beyond the s: the long ships’ reign of terror.

Night Mail

Night Mail is a classic British documentary featuring Benjamin Britten‘s music with W H Auden’s poetry.

From the British Library Website:

‘In 1935, the General Post Office Film Unit decided to produce a documentary to present the new 24-hour postal service between England and Scotland. In July of that year Benjamin Britten met poet W H Auden (1907–73), and their seven year collaboration resulted in stage plays, song settings and films. Their relationship during that time developed from friendship through love to eventual acrimony.

The resulting documentary, Night Mail, is recognised today as a classic of its genre, having been produced with a highly artistic treatment of its subject: a postal train which makes its journey during the night while in one of its carriages staff sorts out the mail for delivery the next day.

The music features in only 4 of the total 24 minutes of the film and is condensed to the end sequence. It alternates between a heavy rhythmic style underlying the syllabic character of the verse reading, and a pastoral style reflecting on the nature and significance of the postal mail.

In this scene, the realistic and factual narration and overall tone of the film is transfigured into an artistic and poetic realm where Auden’s lines are carried forward by Britten’s music. The orchestra and the poem are synchronised with the main protagonist of the film, the postal train. The skillful coordination of sound, music, text and image makes it a significant episode in film history.’ The British Library https://www.bl.uk/works/night-mail

‘Thanks to the classic film which featured it – and for which it was specially written – ‘Night Mail’ remains one of Auden’s best-known poems.’ Dr Oliver Tearle, Interesting Literature

The Night Mail W. H. Auden

This is the night mail crossing the Border,

Bringing the cheque and the postal order,

Letters for the rich, letters for the poor,

The shop at the corner, the girl next door.

Pulling up Beattock, a steady climb:

The gradient’s against her, but she’s on time.

Past cotton-grass and moorland boulder

Shovelling white steam over her shoulder,

Snorting noisily as she passes

Silent miles of wind-bent grasses.

Birds turn their heads as she approaches,

Stare from bushes at her blank-faced coaches.

Sheep-dogs cannot turn her course;

They slumber on with paws across.

In the farm she passes no one wakes,

But a jug in a bedroom gently shakes.

Dawn freshens, Her climb is done.

Down towards Glasgow she descends,

Towards the steam tugs yelping down a glade of cranes

Towards the fields of apparatus, the furnaces

Set on the dark plain like gigantic chessmen.

All Scotland waits for her:

In dark glens, beside pale-green lochs

Men long for news.

Letters of thanks, letters from banks,

Letters of joy from girl and boy,

Receipted bills and invitations

To inspect new stock or to visit relations,

And applications for situations,

And timid lovers’ declarations,

And gossip, gossip from all the nations,

News circumstantial, news financial,

Letters with holiday snaps to enlarge in,

Letters with faces scrawled on the margin,

Letters from uncles, cousins, and aunts,

Letters to Scotland from the South of France,

Letters of condolence to Highlands and Lowlands

Written on paper of every hue,

The pink, the violet, the white and the blue,

The chatty, the catty, the boring, the adoring,

The cold and official and the heart’s outpouring,

Clever, stupid, short and long,

The typed and the printed and the spelt all wrong.

Thousands are still asleep,

Dreaming of terrifying monsters

Or of friendly tea beside the band in Cranston’s or Crawford’s:

Asleep in working Glasgow, asleep in well-set Edinburgh,

Asleep in granite Aberdeen,

They continue their dreams,

But shall wake soon and hope for letters,

And none will hear the postman’s knock

Without a quickening of the heart,

For who can bear to feel himself forgotten?
